Social media It dominates our everyday lives We can barely remember a time when we weren t glued to our phones or even when phone wasn t a ubiquitous term for cell phone or when cell phone wasn t an antiquated term for iPhone or Smartphone Sites like Twitter YouTube and foursquare or Swarm comprise the majority of our everyday online experiences It was Facebook that took it to a level no one could have possibly predicted With the creation of Facebook everyone had a chance to view each other s lives in a way that was not previously conceptualized Or was That s what this film is about The lawsuits that arose after Facebook s founding was called into legal question makes for thrice Oscar nominated cinema that is paralleled by no other Now connecting upwards of 1 7th of humanity Facebook has given rise to people and organizations previously unthinkable in that Harvard dorm room straight out of A Beautiful Mind But this is only the beginning As President and Head Administrator of the Facebook group Future Presidents of the United States and having been contacted by the White House thanks to my efforts I can safely say that Mr Zuckerberg Mr Severin and countless other individuals responsible for the creation and upkeep of Facebook have not yet fully realized the scope and scale of what they have unleashed upon the world The intersection of history and technology has been demonstrated to change the course of humanity throughout various eras I think it s safe to say that this is the beginning of one of those eras Though Facebook turned 11 this past February it s only in its infancy Where will it be at 20 30 50 100 The Internet and Cyberspace in general won t be going anywhere anytime soon Democracy and politics in general won t be going anywhere anytime soon How will Facebook and the Internet in general change the landscape to make way for the most technologically literate generation the world has ever seen Generation Y to not only take the reigns of power but to keep the reigns of power It appears to me that in my many platforms of research that Millennials are somewhat of a novelty We seem to be stuck in a kind of Purgatory neither advancing on the world stage nor shrinking away from it There is no one central figure among us who we can point to and say That s who we are That person represents us That person will more than likely come from Facebook Not necessarily the founders not necessarily its current architects but one of us One of its members And no not necessarily me either I m not looking to gain publicity for the sake of gaining publicity I m just looking to set myself apart from the crowd and call attention to a number of issues facing not only my generation but the generations that will depend on us to receive the passing of the torch The coherency of the message is lost in the roar of the crowd People have to be willing to make themselves vulnerable and stand up for what is right Alone And in this hyper connected day and age that s not something many people are willing or even able to do But I am I am one of many I am not alone I have made it my professional intention to look ahead and ponder the long term future of not only Facebook but the Internet in general This second dimension of humanity isn t going anywhere anytime soon Neither is Facebook It is essential in the everyday lives of billions It all started in a Harvard dorm room Look for sequels to this movie There are a lot more to come

review_title: 9 out of 10 people will "Like" this movie
review_comment: The Social Network Review In American cinema the get rich or die trying mantra is exemplified in several figures from the rugged frontiersman out in the old west The Good the Bad and the Ugly and the Revenant the business tycoon Citizen Kane and Wolf of Wall Street and the various American gangsters fulfilling their ethnic stereotypes Godfather Scarface and the Departed These figures in these movies have many positive qualities like bravery craftiness and determination however they also have many vices greed and thirst for power is the most notable In David Fincher s the Social Network our protagonist is no different Mark Zuckerburg played by Jesse Eisenberg personifies a new generation of anti hero the jaded and insecure computer nerd Mark feels he needs to distinguish himself from others while at the hyper competitive Harvard Mark s motivation to be better however turns into an obsession This obsession to be the best jeopardizes his relationship with everyone who is close to him like his girlfriend and best friend The Social Network succeeds like a good gangster flick by showing how Mark s time at Harvard and his determination to succeed turned him into a monster or as the film would call an asshole An interesting question driving the film is Mark an individual asshole or a byproduct of a narcissistic society By answering the question about Mark it should also make you take a moment to pause and question yourself and wonder if you have ever been an asshole What makes this protagonist so well done is that Mark s online experiences are relatable for many young people watching the film In a new era where everything is online from how beautiful people think you are to messages about your ex that you wish you could take back The Social Network covers a lot of ground about these brand new social dynamics that are still in 2017 are little discussed and it seems like little resistance to social media is given In 2010 Facebook was the premier social network but now the number of apps is only growing from twitter snapchat Instagram tinder and myspace to a name a few okay I am making a joke about the last one no one still uses myspace But these new social networking sites have influenced the way humans interact and how we view each other in our societal hierarchy The networks have changed society with little resistance and little discussion and the Social Network does an excellent job in trying to tackle this issue You will have to watch the movie to see if Mark is ever free from being wired in but it will defiantly make you reconsider both the utility of social networking sites like Facebook and the need to be the best In sum excellent acting and a thoughtful and original script make it worth at least one watch The only con is that the secondary characters have little arc as the protagonist Mark takes center stage Therefore the film could have been stronger if the other characters like Eduardo and Sean weren t so flat and linear

review_comment: David Fincher is one of my favorite directors I had high expectations going into this movie and my expectations were met This movie is not like most other David Fincher movies It doesn t have any twists to it like fight club or seven Its a straight forward incredible true story Even though this movie isn t all true it is still a great story The acting in this movie is very good and i was very impressed with Jesse Eisenberg But the most impressive acting part in this movie is Justin Timberlake I never really liked him unless he was on SNL but he really delivers here and does a great job of making people have mixed emotions about his part Some people will like him and some people will think hes a total douche bag I highly recommend this movie to anyone who likes great screenplays and great acting

review_title: Great Depiction of a person with Asperger's Syndrome
review_comment: I really enjoyed this movie I do not think of a better casting than Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg I feel Eisenburg s performance was far more entailed that Colin Firth s not to take anything away from Firth and should have won the Oscar for Male Lead Preformer As a Computer major in the late 70 s it was enjoyable to see so many personalities that computer programmers possess haven t changed If you read The Accidental Billionaires you will find this movie not only stands up to the book but Eisenberg s portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg to be an incredible interpretation that you almost get lost thinking that Eisenberg is actually Mark Zuckerberg On another note that is close to my hear is in both the book and movie it is obvious that Zuckerberg shows most of the classic traits of a person with Asperger s Syndrome This is a personal observation and in no way indicated that Zuckerberg has been diagnosed with Asperger s Many computer programmers deal with Asperger s Sysdrome Bill Gates being one of the most famous people with Asperger s I think this movie has something for people of all sorts of walks in life from computer geeks programmers Facebook users students health professionals and people curious on how am incredible website like Facebook would come to life I for one knew people in school who shared many of the personalities of the characters in this film and smiled many times as an individual personality would match up with someone I know This is one of the better movies I have watched in a long time

review_title: a true work of filmmaking genius
review_comment: I d put off watching THE SOCIAL NETWORK for a time suspecting it to be a dry and slow moving film After all it was about the guy who founded Facebook so how much fun could it be I didn t much like the idea of watching a film based around people sitting on computers so I was in no hurry to see it Now I ve watched it and things have changed Because THE SOCIAL NETWORK turns out to be one of David Fincher s best films and that s from a director whose filmography is littered with gems This is a hugely entertaining and thoroughly gripping story of success defeat lies and deceit and I was so caught up in the narrative that the two hour running time flew past The joy of THE SOCIAL NETWORK is that it focuses on the conflict between the various parties involved with the founding of one of the world s most popular websites It s bam bam bam with barely time to breathe let alone get bored Good performances are given across the board particularly from Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield two actors I m normally disposed to dislike both of whom are excellent Technical values are unsurprisingly absolutely spectacular and it s clear that Fincher is in his element making a mini masterpiece out of the premise Splendid stuff

When I first hear about this film my initial thought was Yes this is going to make a lot of money chances are its going to be a tacky Hollywood film The Social Network came out in the States before it came out in New Zealand so that gave me abit of time to read other reviews I was shocked to read some people saying things like This film is a flawless masterpiece or This is easily the best film in the last ten years After thinking and talking about The Social Network after getting home from the cinema last night I would say that for the most part this film lives up to its reviews Its almost like i was on the edge of my seat the whole time The dialog is fast It seems that computer geeks talk quickly a joke of course The acting is believable and the script has been beautifully written Justin Timberlake who plays Sean Parker Creator of Napster really impressed me I think he did a brilliant job and in my opinion is a great actor maybe not quite as much as he is a musician but it still did a great job I recommend this film to anyone who wants a intense 2 hours of film 9 10

When I initially heard that a movie was going to be made of Facebook i became instantly sceptical that it was too soon and that a studio was trying desperately to bank off of the social networking phenom during times of tough box office sales When I later found out that Fincher was pushing the vehicle of this massive potential for a motion picture I took a sigh of relief and began looking forward to the release date Having seen the movie twice now I am certain that Fincher did us all a great big favor by providing us with a great analysis of the history behind the man and the movement of Facebook Mr Eisenberg is cut to perfection in this film and with the great direction of Aaron Sorkin s fast paced and edgy script the formula is set for a perfect dynamic The quick paced dialogue allows us a perception into Zuckerberg brain an overwhelming high adrenaline hard to keep up with mind THe edginess to his character compounded with the back and forth motion of the past and present scene sequence is great in showing how quickly things moved and how fast everything was going for these kids It s really a great film to see whether or not one is a fan of facebook For those who have seen pirates of silicon valley a story of the developments of Mac and PC and the rivaling feud of Steve Jobs and Bill Gates when computers were slowly rising as personal desktops the social network is somewhat reminiscent of that film in the way that young bright college minds push on an idea are completely smitten with the business and corporate world and become instant rock stars of their time It s great seeing the roots being planted of an idea that is capable of changing the whole online and social networking world Fan or not of facebook i highly recommend watching this Fincher flick

Even if I am a facebook user I have not read yet any history about its foundation The movie was really interesting and explained easily the born and the growth of this social network It was interesting as well to find Justin Timberlake as actor of this movie The storytelling was easy and interesting to follow When we took the movie from the store we thought it could one of those boring movies telling you the story as a documentary But maybe due to the particular history of facebook this movie shows us the opposite Every minute was interesting to watch Every minute give you the possibility to learn how this big social media growth up where the ideas came from and overall the difficulties related to its development It is quite funny the end of the movie An action which I am used to see in many facebook users

review_title: One of the best films of 2010 for sure.
review_comment: I skipped out on the social network when it first released back in 2010 I was fourteen at the time and watching the promos and trailers for it really only made me think A movie about Facebook I ll pass thanks but having watched the movie for a second time now after noticing a lot of praise for it and coming to be a little more accepting to genres and actors I hadn t been very into before and seeing Andrew Garfield s performance in Hacksaw Ridge I can honestly say this movie is probably one of my favorite of the decade so far In all honesty it s not a movie about Will Facebook become successful despite the lawsuit since we all know that it does It s a movie about the deterioration of friendships and how the idea of success can come to change someone It s beautifully acted and Aaron Sorkin s dialogue is some of the best I ve ever seen It s never boring even at it s slowest and it s definitely worth a watch

If you want to get motivated for college go ahead and watch The Social Network directed by David Fincher it s on Netflix at the moment The script written by Aaron Sorkin is witty sharp and has an almost musical quality that makes you want to tour encyclopedias cover to cover while listening to drumbeat patterns You can t help but hang on to every meticulously uttered word The dialogue is spoken with confidence unmoving and absolute it makes real life seem dull in comparison The soundtrack by Nine Inch Nails provides a haunting atmosphere that sounds like a combination of beeping computer hardware the twinkling melody of innovation and the crushing roar of loneliness under the guise of the ultimate popularity The tone of the movie would be different if there were mellow upbeat guitar twangs and drum crashes rather than this melancholy masterpiece The immediately recognizable triplet of piano notes that occasionally weaves in and out of the score is haunting The lack of stereotypical shots of glory where the music crescendos and the orchestra goes fortissimo makes for droning electronically harsh sounds to fill up the background in such an omnipresent and subtle way that you don t even register when the music picks up the marriage of sound to scene is so darn tight It s surprising when you go listen to the soundtrack itself and hear the screeching blasts of audio that could only come from machine Was that in the movie Yes it was quite loud too The lighting set design and cinematography are just magnificent The warm ambient lighting of Harvard dorms and legal deposition rooms shroud the scenes with such a cozy intimacy that I myself watch this film when I m sick and want to feel comfortable The iconic campus of Harvard is majestic you could very well believe that the cement holding the reddish brown brick together contains the very foundations of knowledge itself Prestigious Harvard banners litter dorm room backgrounds as drinking undergrads party the night away reminding you that even students at the highest level of academia know how get loose as they gyrate half naked on an ottoman to the hottest new pop track Sick The modern designs of furniture later in the film are not only a signal to the passing of time they re the embodiment of current era tech they re sleek gunmetal grey ergonomic and downright sexy Fincher s shots are gorgeous as hell his preference for static camerawork means there are innumerable moments where you could pause the film and BOOM put it on a poster and nobody would question its validity The acting performances are without flaw I can t imagine any other actor in the place of Jesse Eisenberg Justin Timberlake plays the role of a cunning and crafty entrepreneur a little too well and Andrew Garfield is so much more than a webslinger in spandex All these components of the film come together to form an immensely satisfying piece of art a masterclass in filmmaking that keeps me coming back for more Maybe feeling ill isn t so bad As for the substance well there s a lot This film has a lot of themes it depicts the rustle and tussle underneath the glittering waters of wildly successful enterprise and within that picture you get lessons on relatinships class betrayal ambition greed jealousy breakthrough fulfilment comradery and a smorgasbord of other messages worth thinking about There are so many different ways in which you can view this film and each angle is as riveting and as lucid as the rest The Social Network is very much a modern film yet it has themes that stretch back to the innovative Shakespearian literature Looking past the more grandiose messages you get my favorite element from the story The Social Network is about living among an incredibly intelligent high achieving population and attempting the tough task of separating yourself from the rest of the lot Mark Zuckerberg is FOCUSED on his pursuit of distinction This film makes you want to go to college and not just get solid GPAs and internships it makes you want to offer something far larger than that something groundbreaking something that changes the game It makes you want to SPEND your youth instead of merely LIVING it It makes you want to THRIVE instead of SURVIVING in college The theme of how some wildly ambitious kids tromping near the eve of their primes managed to build a social network that promptly took over the entire world and permeated the thick barriers of billions of skulls seeping into the know is nothing short of inspirational In the industry there exists tons of feel good films that seek to motivate you but those motivational messages are lost when translated to reality there s too much sunshine too much rainbow and then they have the audacity to tell us that there s even a pot of gold at the end The Social Network is serious it s not afraid of imperfection of blemish of the ugly no it assertively informs us of it The invigorating message of The Social Network isn t something the film actively advertises it sits prettily at the core there for us to derive It s an alternative take to the Scarface esque neon red inscription on a golden globe statue the world is yours Only instead of guns cocaine on the tip of your nose and Michelle Pfeiffer in a sleek dress it s computers coffee under your breath and Rooney Mara on an LCD laptop screen System out println The world truly is yours I m recommending what s probably the most significant film of the past decade Its social commentary historical significance and motivational inclinations are all packaged up in an aesthetically pleasing format that we will look back at in awe later in the future I guarantee it It deserved every accolade it got and more lost respect for The Oscars after finding out The King s Speech won best picture over this Do yourself a favor and go watch The Social Network Fincher you damn genius let me throw my money at you respectfully

review_title: A great movie about becoming a friend
review_comment: The movie does a great job at making people strongly dislike Mark showing different situations where he is in a grey to dark grey area of right and wrong We see his arc fluctuate between being in the wrong to being wronged Its a great movie that teaches the masses about supply and demand a wonderful example for economics classes to use as a point of teaching

Overall the movie was very well directed and sophisticated In fact the only flaw I found with this movie is that it may have been a bit too sophisticated at times As someone who is not as technologically savvy as Mark Zuckerberg I often found it hard to understand what he was talking about Although I am aware that the reason Jesse Eisenberg s lines as Mark Zuckerberg were so advanced in vocabulary was to portray Mark as accurately as possible it made it hard for viewers such as myself to fully grasp what was going on Other than that this film was astounding It really helped me get to know Mark as more than just the founder of Facebook When I first learned that we would be watching this film in class I had very low hopes to be quite honest as I had never even heard about this movie before I am glad that I was wrong and I actually ended up liking this movie very much It was about more than just the creation of Facebook It was about friendship and betrayal as well as supply and demand In this case Facebook allowing its users to connect and interact with one another is the supply whereas its users desire to connect with others is the demand As demand went up so did the supply which is what would lead to Mark becoming the youngest billionaire at that time Overall it was an exceptional film and well worth the watch

This movie on first viewing was a spectacle to my brain It doesn t use flashy special effects or action but instead uses flashy dialogue and editing to really keep the viewer watching The snappy clever dialogue thats written makes every line rememberable and it really stuck to me days after watching it The acting was amazing especially from Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg Andrew Garfield as Eduardo Saverin and even Justin Timberlake as Sean Parker These actors convey such emotion through their characters they seem like they were born for the roll The scene I always come back to without spoilers is emotional climax The acting pacing dialogue all comes together so perfectly that the scene resonates so well afterward Rewatches are even more entertaining because you can pick out new info and touches you never saw during the times before Its the only movie I rewatched twice after I saw it for the first time Brilliant

A seemingly boring fact computernerd designs popular website becomes in the hands of a master director a dazzling and energetic drama with fantastic renditions of the entire cast This seemingly physical role also made me aware of Jesse Eisenberg for the first time and every time I see him in a later or earlier made film I still have to think about this role for a moment Compliments also for Justin Timberlake as the slick Sean Parker but as said all the actors are great The complex narrative structure doesn t stand in the way of the clarity of the plot at all and keeps the film captivating at all times cleverly exposing all points of view Those who ignore The social network because they don t have Facebook after all miss out on something if only because the film is not only about Facebook but also about friendship social status the problems surrounding intellectual property and the temptations of corporate business

review_title: Wow! One of these films that really makes you think about its story.
review_comment: To be fair when I first discovered The social Network and saw its success regarding prices and reviews from both fans and critics I only thought to myself Why Why make a movie about the platform that owns the communication Channels of half of world s population and only focus on its origin But after I got several recommendations from Colleagues and Friends on Campus I got curios How can a movie about the origin of Facebook impress so many people around me So I gave it a shot And boy was I wrong This Movie is a masterpiece From the deep yet disturbing soundtrack to the brilliant cinematography and creativity of each shot to the fearsome Acting of Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg and especially Andrew Garfield as his Roommate and Friend Eduardo Severin I am no professional film critic but I know that when a movie catches me and makes me think about it days and even weeks after I saw it there must be something special about it David Fyncher knows how to set up a Drama and here this experience really shines The story starts with Zuckerberg creating Facesmash a website to rate female Students on Harvard Campus after he got rejected by his Date which becomes so popular among students that the whole Campus Network crashes the same night From there on Zuckerberg is possessed by his idea to take the whole social experience in college online which ultimately leads him to conflicts with his Friend and Roommate Eduardo Severin and the Winklevoss Brothers who had a similar Idea and accuse him of stealing their Business Idea During the whole film you can really see how the Facebook that was created by a Computer Nerd and his Roommate at University slowly takes its way to become the multibillion dollar company we know today And this way is not only marked by the genius of Zuckerberg and his vision to make Facebook a global phenomenon but also by the loss of friendship greed egoism and treason A tragic combination that slowly unveils the true price of success All while the story is embedded in the two litigations between Zuckerberg and Severin on the one hand and Zuckerberg and the Winklevoss Brothers on the other When the credits finally rolled I sat there thinking about what I just saw Even after nearly a week I find myself thinking about Zuckerberg s story about his impact on modern society and communication and also about the fact that a young 19 year old Harvard Student could create and realize a vision of the future many older experienced people could not see nor build Would the world be a worse place if Facebook was never invented Did Zuckerberg really revolutionize the way we communicate Or did his actions and the rise of Facebook create something we would have never thought of if he had not been the one to realize his own vision We will never know But we certainly know that Facebook shaped modern society in the last 20 Years like no other company has and may also shape our future whether by itself or by the competition its own success has created The Social Network is a well written thought provoking drama that delivers on all fronts and in my opinion truly earns it s praise by fans critics If you decide to watch The social Network make sure to watch the official trailer first The trailer for this movie is already a masterpiece itself and catches the tone of the story to near perfection

If you have ever been curious of the back story of Facebook or it s creator Mark Zuckerberg then this film is for you It shows insights on how the website was created and the legalities Zuckerberg went through to proclaim his ownership Although the movie is interesting it is not a film that I would recommend freely I would recommend to those who show interest or curiosity This film is for those interested in the origin story of one of the largest and fastest growing social media networks Prior to watching this film I would have never guessed the legal or business aspects of a website and am happy to see that side of it

I d put off watching THE SOCIAL NETWORK for a time suspecting it to be a dry and slow moving film After all it was about the guy who founded Facebook so how much fun could it be I didn t much like the idea of watching a film based around people sitting on computers so I was in no hurry to see it Now I ve watched it and things have changed Because THE SOCIAL NETWORK turns out to be one of David Fincher s best films and that s from a director whose filmography is littered with gems This is a hugely entertaining and thoroughly gripping story of success defeat lies and deceit and I was so caught up in the narrative that the two hour running time flew past The joy of THE SOCIAL NETWORK is that it focuses on the conflict between the various parties involved with the founding of one of the world s most popular websites It s bam bam bam with barely time to breathe let alone get bored Good performances are given across the board particularly from Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield two actors I m normally disposed to dislike both of whom are excellent Technical values are unsurprisingly absolutely spectacular and it s clear that Fincher is in his element making a mini masterpiece out of the premise Splendid stuff

review_title: Perfect integration of humour into an otherwise serious film.
review_comment: Dramatic films are usually solely dramatic Humorous films are usually solely humorous The Social Network truly creates the best of both worlds and provides a sense of humour laced with satire irony and sarcasm from a true genius Mark Zuckerberg The lines were absolutely fantastic with every line having a deeper effect than the last Mark lives his life with a condescending manner towards anyone and everyone and prides himself on his true coding genius There are somber and stern moments as well as lighthearted and funny moments showcasing the contrasting sides of Mark s life The story of the origin of Facebook is undoubtedly quite entertaining but the overabundance of characters sometimes becomes too much Furthermore there is a slight divide between the characters and the audience because they are portrayed at an almost superficial intellectual level far superior to most audience members hence making it hard for the audience to connect Nonetheless The Social Network was an overall enjoyable film and gave me some nice Friday night entertainment

One of the most prominent criticisms of The Social Network is that it is a complete dramatization and isn t even close to what happened in real life The reason for this is that what happened in real life was completely boring Mark Zuckerburg and his friends were just a bunch of computer geeks sitting around a computer in their room writing line after line of computer code If a movie accurately portrayed hacking in real life it would be one of the most boring movies ever made So of course this movie is a complete dramatization You don t go to the movies and expect it to be completely based off of fact The Social Network was a well written movie that takes the boring tale of the creation of facebook and the drama that ensued and turns it into a full blown captivating story that will keep your attention throughout the entire length of the movie It is based off of a book written by Ben Mezrich a Harvard Magna Cum Laudi graduate Which is probably the reason why it is such a thrilling script I have never read the book but the movie did a good job of following a storyline even with so much to cover The two lawsuits that the main plot of the story is based around makes a very good baseline in which everything that the movie talks about ties back to This keeps the movie on task never trekking too far off topic yet keeping the scenes flowing easily from one to the next My one complaint is that the movie was fairly over dramatic Every scene in the movie was either some really flashy over the top party scene some stupid teenage stunt scene or a scene in which people were consistently whining at each other At a certain point in the movie I just wanted everybody to get over their hormonal crying and do something Punch someone Sue them Don t just sit there and complain about it However I am probably biased on this issue as I am not a fan of useless and incompetent drama which was what this movie was all about If you are a fan of such drama then you will probably enjoy The Social Network that much more The director of this movie was David Fincher I want to briefly mention this because Fincher has directed a couple of fairly decent movies in the past such as Fight Club and Se7en He continues his trend of decent movie making in this movie However the writing and story are what make this movie Fincher only adds to the decency of the movie I am even less focused on the acting in any movie Actors are just the face of a movie they aren t what make it a good movie Anyone given enough makeup practice and enough times in front of the camera can act well It takes some amount of intelligence to write direct or even know when to invest in a good movie If you have terrible actors but good directing and writing you can end up with a well thought out movie Nonetheless if you must have my opinion on the acting of this film I guess they did a good job as well The characters did seem to line up well with their actors There is one very important topic I do want to discuss While watching this movie I started to realize that it was created in such a way that it was impartial towards the characters There were no blatant bad or good guys It was just people doing what they do and then suffering the consequences of their actions Is this a good thing Should media be neutral Well may be It depends on what the type of media is trying to do Arguing a strict point can hinder intellectual pondering of the moral If a movie portrays that this man is good and that man is bad then you aren t going to think about why what this man is good or why that man is bad because it s fairly obvious You might question the legitimacy of the movie s claim but if you re going to do that then you probably already do that with most media or at least the media that doesn t measure up to your personal political or moral beliefs Most people will just watch and accept So this is the way people use if the creator is trying to impose a strict moral through their medium However this can also alienate certain populations from enjoying certain movies It is hard to like a movie when you don t agree with what it is trying to tell you Machete would have been an awesome note that I said awesome not good movie if it wasn t so politically involved On the other hand if a movie is neutral then it can be hard to portray any sort of meaning Although I don t find this to be an entirely bad thing Like ancient Grecian or Shakespearian tragic plays a person has to think about why Creon ended his life with nothing or why Macbeth had it all and then lost it I like to sit down to a movie and then leave thinking about what I just watched and why it ended the way it did not just blindly accept that this person was right and that person was wrong Well back to the movie Should you go and see The Social Network I say yes It might not be the best movie of the year but it was a well written well developed movie Even if you hate drama don t have a facebook or even know who Sean Parker is you should still see this movie

In 1987 Oliver Stone produced a film that encapsulated a whole era and captured the Zeitgeist perfectly the character of Gordon Gekko crystallising the most prevalent of the seven deadly sins of the time In 2010 Stone is set on repeating this trick by attempting to pull off one of the hardest tasks in the film industry the sequel that matches up to its predecessor The timing seems perfect with the current financial crisis reflecting the true bust of the late eighties boom and the impending release of the original film s central character in real time However his film has been eclipsed by The Social Network As the seventies had All The President s Men the eighties had Stone s aforementioned Wall Street the nineties had The Insider and now after a decade without a major time capsule of a film the new millennium has The Social Network With The Social Network slamming Wall Street 2 at the box office it seems that while Stone has been missing the mark with presidential bio pics and fumbling around South America stroking the egos of Bolivarian political leaders his position that he earned cutting his teeth or should that be grinding his teeth working on Scarface as the major socio political commentator director has been usurped by a younger model in the form of David Fincher Presenting the skills he has crafted and honed since his 1995 breakthrough picture Se7en Fincher is backed by a killer script from The West Wing s Aaron Sorkin It is testament to Sorkin s ability that he managed to pull it off The facebook story is RAM full of absolutely un writable characters After all if you were to conjure a pair of opponents for Zuckerberg upon the battlefield of intellectual property would you have chosen identical twin Olympic rowers christened with the inimitable moniker of Winklevoss I wouldn t imagine so But it is in characters such as these that some of the wittiest of dialogue comes as one of the twins negates the need to hire someone for the job of intimidating facebook founder Mark Zuckerburg I m 6 4 weigh 220 pounds and there s two of me Fincher has also assembled a great cast A handful of the best young actors in America appear in this movie Jesse Eisenberg s portrayal of the character is so deft and on point that we are treated to a mesmerising display that excels past even the usual high standard of performance Fincher manages to extract from his casts He is ever unlikable ever untrustworthy and ever petty but does manage a small amount of sympathy in being that guy we all know one that brilliant borderline genius without a clue If Zuckerberg is truly anything like Eisenberg s version then an argument for Asperger syndrome stands on firm footing Andrew Garfield continues to impress slightly twisting and improving his character and performance adeptly from the film Lions For Lambs earlier in the decade playing original facebook CFO Eduardo Saverin I doubt however that the script or demand on his acting ability will match up to this role in the upcoming Spiderman movies Despite these two lead characters portrayed so excellently it is Justin Timberlake who shines as Napster founder Sean Parker In a pivotal scene Parker sums up the ideology of today s intelligent and irreverent youth echoing Michael Douglas as Gordon Gekko giving the greed is good speech in 1987 verbally wrapping up the 80s yuppie mentality I can smell the outside bet for Best Supporting Actor at next year s Oscars now And I m sure this will pick up a whole load of nominations elsewhere and maybe some statuettes Lord knows it deserves every accolade it receives 2010

Mark Zuckerberg And His Lessons For Entrepreneurs Mark Zuckerberg is a genius who used the power of his mind to see the invisible needs of visible human beings Something that management guru C K Prahlad called as Strategic Intent many decades back Mark also saw what he had in him and how to use it what he didn t have and where or who to get it from Mark Zuckerberg is also a shark who used the power of his mind to bite the lesser species Homo Sapiens v1 0 Homo Sapiens v1 9 in every weak spot at every opportunity For example in a court scene when the jury begs for attention Mark says his mind is on something so different that his opponents don t even have the intellectual ability to think of but will claim to be theirs But the script would have demanded that As to how Mark says the many things he says one should only see the movie to experience it Standing tall and heard the loudest was his line If you were the inventors of Facebook you would have invented Facebook All other actors are better than the best I have seen in my life but nowhere near Mark In the way I experienced it the movie is a lesson on how entrepreneurs can sow a seed called idea see them germinate to become a plant and how the plant needs to be watered so that the buds can blossom And all this has to happen at the speed of light It also highlights the importance of acknowledging the role of mentors and having the right mentors to make the unimaginable become real Is There Anything Immoral Or Unethical About Mark Businesses thrive and flourish on the greed of its founders However this greed should be directed at the competition and not on the Co Founders in letter and spirit A fact acknowledged by the court when Eduardo won his case With the money he now has he can buy the world but if ever he goes bankrupt in his lifetime again he can never get the spirit of Eduardo Saverin to be with him At no stage of the movie does the viewer get an impression that Mark Zuckerberg is An Accidental Billionaire It this technology age it always looked like a windfall that was waiting to happen Somewhere along the way if the Mark Zuckerbergs can be a bit more fair moral and ethical to the Eduardo Saverins of the world who as buddies extend every possible help in the embryonic stages of the business on money matters and not short change them the world will be a better place for entrepreneurs and the people whose families depend on them for livelihood Otherwise the Zuckerbergs suck and no wonder Mark is a Harvard drop out because there was one thing Harvard would have tried to teach him ethical and moral obligations and he would never learn

review_title: Worth watching, even if a touch longer than necessary
review_comment: How far can one girl drive a guy to go That question is at the core of The Social Network The movie follows Mark Zuckerberg Jesse Eisenberg through all of the twists and turns of developing his now famous Facebook web site The social scene of America s elite universities portrayed as elitist filled with peer pressure and driven towards getting what you want provides the backdrop for the legal battles between both Mark and his friend Eduardo as well as a group of students from one of the most prestigious clubs on campus The money involved however is always secondary to the more important issues of status and social standing and the contrast of that pressure with developing actual friendships It is also of course about that one girl Erica a BU student who we first meet in a bar with Mark whose occasional appearances remind us of what gets Mark started in the first place The movie s story is definitely compelling giving us flashback insights into the process by which Facebook became a social phenomenon Though most of us know how successful the site ends up being I even got into this site through Facebook we are still left intrigued by the complicated process which drives the site forward from its humble beginnings in a Harvard dorm room The college social scene that is at the heart of the movie is also skillfully articulated with Trent Reznor s musical influence providing a tremendous soundtrack that highlights its darker undertones The film also raises a number of great questions about what it means to be social in the 21st century how are our relationships shaped by technology and in reverse how has technology developed in response to the way our relationships have already changed How we can develop a whole social network and lose all our real friends in the process creates the powerful but disturbing narrative behind this film There are a few weaknesses in the movie The story does not seem to fill the entire 120 minutes with lulls where the plot is moving a bit slowly and the characters do not provide enough of an emotional connection to keep things interesting Cutting 15 20 minutes and or further developing some of the secondary characters may have helped the story feel more consistently strong The rest of the movie s strengths however more than make up for these weaknesses and make this film well worth watching and then perhaps posting a note about on Facebook

I d put off watching THE SOCIAL NETWORK for a time suspecting it to be a dry and slow moving film After all it was about the guy who founded Facebook so how much fun could it be I didn t much like the idea of watching a film based around people sitting on computers so I was in no hurry to see it Now I ve watched it and things have changed Because THE SOCIAL NETWORK turns out to be one of David Fincher s best films and that s from a director whose filmography is littered with gems This is a hugely entertaining and thoroughly gripping story of success defeat lies and deceit and I was so caught up in the narrative that the two hour running time flew past The joy of THE SOCIAL NETWORK is that it focuses on the conflict between the various parties involved with the founding of one of the world s most popular websites It s bam bam bam with barely time to breathe let alone get bored Good performances are given across the board particularly from Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield two actors I m normally disposed to dislike both of whom are excellent Technical values are unsurprisingly absolutely spectacular and it s clear that Fincher is in his element making a mini masterpiece out of the premise Splendid stuff

The AMC theater in Times Square offered the perfect atmosphere to watch Jesse Eisenberg and Justin Timberlake star in The Social Network a drama about the popular networking site Facebook He s wired in is a common line quoted by characters in the fictional film The Social Network directed by David Fincher After viewing this movie opening weekend I realized the term wired in is the perfect way to describe how captivated I was by the film The Social Network created in 2010 follows the formation of Facebook by its founder Mark Zuckerberg The film creatively flashes back between the time line of its deceptive creation and simultaneous lawsuits against Zuckerberg by his former best friend Eduardo Saverin and three classmates The plot follows Zuckerberg and Saverin as they spontaneously create the Facebook site while studying at Harvard University Convinced the idea for Facebook was originally theirs twins Caermon and Tyler WInklevoss sue Zuckerberg for the rights to the site As the plot evolves Napster co founder Sean Parker enters the scene and corrupts the mind of Zuckerberg eventually leading to his betrayal of Saverin Viewing the film at AMC in Times Square definitely made the experience very different than it would have been if I watched the film alone It was unique to learn about Facebook in a theater with my two friends but also with a handful of strangers I remember thinking how awesome it was that almost everyone watching the movie with me also had their very own Facebook account The intense focus from the audience was evident as no one spoke or made comments throughout the entire film As far as the atmosphere AMC theater is a very familiar and comfortable theater for me The ticket price was more expensive at 13 yet these are not surprising for New York City prices Despite it being opening weekend I was surprised at how quickly lines moved and how friendly the employees were Once inside the theater my seat was comfortable and I anxiously awaited the start of the film Before the film began I was happy to discover there were not any commercials and instead there was the perfect amount of trailers As trailers are my favorite part of a movie experience my friends and I loved critiquing the future films together Though some may argue the movie is not a clear indication of the history of Facebook I think Fincher did an amazing job of translating the story with an air of suspense I thought the characters casted portrayed the types of personalities respectively and believably Timberlake for instance did a fantastic job of straying away from the typical romantic comedy character he usually plays Instead he managed to pull off the deceptive pretty boy personality of Parker convincingly and successfully The script was well written and filled with intelligent lines that sold the seriousness of the story to the viewers With the two lawsuits intertwined with the past narrative the clever combination of scenes definitely kept me as a viewer on the edge of my seat

review_title: This movie was an OK, but dry documentary
review_comment: Well acted for the most part It Seems to be a quite factual and yet a completely middle of the road true story I find that there is very little that is remarkable about the people who created Facebook But then Facebook itself is not necessarily remarkable given that all the programming architecture contained within it already existed at least 5 years before it s time the difference being not all elements were combined into one complete suite I found The Pirates of Silicon Valley to be a much more compelling if a somewhat more sensationalized version on other programmers lives and success stories Both movies end with a somewhat bittersweet end and perhaps teach us that money and success is truly not the only ingredients towards leading a happy life This movie is worth watching if you have a desire to learn more about the software industry in North America

The Social Network 2010 is a film based off of the story of how the social networking site Facebook was created The film stars Jesse Eisenburg as founder Mark Zuckerberg Andrew Garfield as co founder Eduardo Saverin and Justin Timberlake as Napster founder Sean Parker The movie depicts the development of the social networking site as well as the obstacles Mark faces with lawsuits dealing with him stealing the idea of Facebook and diluting Eduardo s shares once the company grew The theme of The Social Network deals with inspiration betrayal and the cost of success Mark is inspired by his own idea of Facemash which was a website used to rate female students on attractiveness After being invited by Camerson and Tyler Winklevoss to be a part of the creation of their social site called The Harvord Connection Mark decided to expand his idea of Facemash into Facebook Mark and co founder Eduardo work to get Facebook launched and running and expand to other schools very quickly I believe the instant success was too much for Mark to handle as he proves in the movie he is easily influenced by Sean Parker This causes Mark to betray Eduardo when he is convinced to reduce Eduardo s shares of the company to nearly nothing The lighting throughout the film is very low key I believe this gave the feeling of realness as well as seriousness While Mark is hard at work creating the website in his apartment the lights are low which also shows him concentrating The cuts that transitioned from the story of the creation of Facebook to the current day lawsuit hearings was done very clearly and smoothly The film as well as the cuts were easy to follow and very well written The actors did a great job of portraying the actual people and made the viewer believe Although the film has been criticized for not being completely accurate the directors and writers did a great job of keeping a neutral point of view throughout as well as illustrating many different points of view including Mark Eduardo and the Winklevoss twins I very much enjoyed the film just as I suspected I would I found it to be very interesting and as a Facebook user myself it made the meaning of it even more personal

review_title: A story of friendship and betrayal
review_comment: The social network is a drama directed by David Fincher and written by Aaron Sorkin The movie follows the journey of a 19 year old computer major of Harvard Mark Zukerberg who is played by Jesse Eisenberg The movie begins with an unpleasant date in a dark lit bar with his girlfriend now ex Erica Albright played by Rooney Mara The dark atmosphere helps to set the mood of the friendly conversation that will soon become unpleasant This scene depicts an argument over Marks attempt to get into a Final Club which Erica doesn t understand The over the shoulder angles quickly switch back and forth keeping the viewer into the in depth conversation As the conversation becomes more intense the cameras become closer and closer to the actors faces putting you into their seat almost This scene sets the whole movie into motion Filled with frustration and slightly intoxicated Mark lashes out at the women at Harvard by creating a small website to rate the look of women side by side The new websites impressive growth and popularity over a span of hours draws attention to him by the Winklevoss twins both played by Armie Hammer The Winklevoss brothers present an idea for a Social Network site to Mark who quickly decides to help The movie then begins to focus its theme on the value of friendships With the new project underway Mark dodges calls and emails from the twins while he works on his own social site that is greatly parallel to that of the twin s idea Marks friend Eduardo Saverin played by Andrew Garfield helps fund his website called Thefacebook which was exclusive to only Harvard students As time passes the popularity of Thefacebook greatly increases both causing legal issues with the twins for theft of intellectual property and gains attention from Napster founder Sean Parker played by Justin Timberlake Sean decides it is time to expand the Thefacebook which is later renamed Facebook and he puts his best foot forward to help expand the website while taking his fair chunk of profits From here on in you see many conflicts of friendships and betrayal between many of the characters mostly by intercut scenes of Mark in a room full of lawyers trying to settle with both Eduardo and the Winklevoss twins I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys an in depth pop culture movie The creativity behind it is pure genius and is a must see not just once but multiple time

review_title: One of the best movies I've ever seen!
review_comment: There s too many things to list as to why this movie flows so so well Although I believe it has a lot to do with Mr Fincher

The Director David Fincher and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin rush through a series of attempts and failures achievements and disloyalty ending with what feels like a gloominess conclusion on an lonely soul This film is extremely entertaining and feels like a psychologically roller coaster The film is created around a depressed inconsistency in 2003 Mark Zuckerberg played by Jesse Eisenberg is a 19 year old sophomore at Harvard Mark formulates Facebook and ultimately creates a 500 million person network of friends but he is so narcissistic driven and introverted that he can t stay close to anyone Mark dumps his one and only real friend Eduardo Saverin Andrew Garfield who is also a student at Harvard and assisted in helping Mark initiate the social network The film The Social Network contains amazing satire because the inner theme is not connectivity but rather a disconnection This movie is about the beginning of a technology calculated to get people closer together and showcases a main character who learns the agonizing disbanding of social connections The theme has a strong connection with the movie You ve Got Mail The new technology shows how social connections can be made without really understanding the real life connections that goes along with it The Social Network contains social disbanding is weakened by its swarming network of known friendly signifiers It implies that yes was friends with these signifiers as much as we are friends with hundreds or thousands of people on Facebook As represented in the film the social site doesn t really carry people together in a significant way The film contains dissimilar lawsuit depositions as the movies framing tool it follows this intellectual but socially uncomfortable student Mark Zuckerberg as he heads down the path moving to Facebook after breaking up with by a girl he likes Rooney Mara As an Internet joke he pulls for redemption for his punishment lands him in a mess with the Harvard board members At the same time he gathers the attention from other wealth Harvard students who would otherwise keep away from him the Winklevoss twin brothers Josh Pence Armie Hammer They offer him a job to work on their social site and later claim he stole their idea Mark also gets sued by his once best and only real friend Eduardo Saverin Andrew Garfield Eduado was one of the original investors to start the site Mark envisioned Mark is eventually courted by Sean Parker Justin Timerlake the owner of the music site Napster Sean convinces Mark to move his site home base to Silicon Valley to allow access to wealth venture capitalists seeking outside inventors The last scene in my opinion contains the mastery of the film by never breaking the 180 degrees during the heated conversation between Mark and Erica This meeting illustrates the spectator more into the story because there is a smaller amount of a need to resituate the person within the scene The motif that all of us can relate to is that social acceptance occurs throughout the film Mark is building Facebook because he is trying to gain social acceptance The scene that highlights this the most is when Erica questions Mark s fascination with Final Clubs because of the influence they supply its members Facebook is shown as a social network but it also shows the variations from the competitive sites The film itself is more about the creation of Facebook and the history of how the company was started more than the actual social networking site itself The movie is really about human actions more than anything else How personal agendas and greed sometimes get ahead of friendship morals and teamwork

review_title: Yet Another Excellent Film By David Fincher
review_comment: When I heard about the film The Social Network I was a bit confused I wondered how David Fincher director of films like Fight Club and Se7en was going to pull off a movie about Mark Zuckerberg and his triumph up the social hierarchy towards his fame and stardom through Facebook After I saw this film I was absolutely amazed by how the director of such gritty crime thrillers could direct an amazing biography drama of a Harvard student creating Facebook Fincher takes up and coming star Jesse Eisenberg and turned him into to an Oscar nominee for best performance by an actor in a leading role This movie offers much more than just a kid making a web page but how through the process what he must give up and what he must gain to make it work If you are looking for a great movie with an intriguing story line excellent acting and articulate dialogue then watch The Social Network

review_title: The Social Network (2010) is a biographical drama by American director David Fincher, starring Jesse Eisenberg, Andrew Garfield, Justin Timberlake and Rooney Mara.
review_comment: I could say that I am a big fan of David Fincher s work I have seen all of his best work Fight Club 1999 Se7en 1995 Gone Girl 2014 The Curious Case of Benjamin Button 2008 and Zodiac 2007 Three of them are my favorite films of all time A lot of his films have won Oscars or have been nominated for one The Social Network tells a story about Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg who creates the social media site which nowadays we know as Facebook but is later sued by two brothers who claimed he stole their idea and the co founder who was later pushed out of the business I really liked the film although I saw it the first time few years ago after it had came out I liked it because it was so inspiring that after watching it I wanted to go and do something creative on my own I liked that it was really dramatic it was a true drama the main character went thru hell but in the end almost everything was fine I like that it shows the struggles of teenagers life the difficulties in student life how hard is university and how hard you need to work to get what you want It shows what is the actual price to make a company that ears millions There s no other film like this that is why it is so special

review_title: Good Biography, not the best movie
review_comment: It s a fantastic movie if one wants to know the story behind one of our greatest social networks right now While it actually is a good describing of the situation and especially the conflicts approaching when Facebook gets started it is not the best movie in things like stylistic devices or impressing use of camera perspective or anything else it s just a biography and that s okay If you are not that much interested in Facebook or don t want to educate yourself the movie are two wasted hours it will start to get boring and more boring though if you want to have fun or get an story filled up with action there are many better movies I give 7 10 because i liked to know more i like Rooney Mara she s a fantastic actress and i also liked Jesse Eisenberg as Mark Zuckerberg but wouldn t watch the movie if i wasn t interested

financed and sponsored his projects The big problem begin when Sean Parker was contracted by Mark and when the brother Winklevoss and their friend heard about Mark project they knew they have to do review_title: The Social Network: Is it discouraging?
review_comment: I d put off watching THE SOCIAL NETWORK for a time suspecting it to be a dry and slow moving film After all it was about the guy who founded Facebook so how much fun could it be I didn t much like the idea of watching a film based around people sitting on computers so I was in no hurry to see it Now I ve watched it and things have changed Because THE SOCIAL NETWORK turns out to be one of David Fincher s best films and that s from a director whose filmography is littered with gems This is a hugely entertaining and thoroughly gripping story of success defeat lies and deceit and I was so caught up in the narrative that the two hour running time flew past The joy of THE SOCIAL NETWORK is that it focuses on the conflict between the various parties involved with the founding of one of the world s most popular websites It s bam bam bam with barely time to breathe let alone get bored Good performances are given across the board particularly from Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield two actors I m normally disposed to dislike both of whom are excellent Technical values are unsurprisingly absolutely spectacular and it s clear that Fincher is in his element making a mini masterpiece out of the premise Splendid stuff

review_title: The Social Network- the best film of all time?
review_comment: David Fincher has directed many thrilling and perceptive films in the past however his latest film can be seen as his best work yet Fincher doesn t just explore the obvious ideas of personal theft violation contradiction and inhuman endeavors we are taken inside the minds of Zuckerberg we are taken into this world of social manipulation and categorization and we are inadvertently left creeping behind the door yearning to identify more of what our societies future offers Facebook is used as a tool to portray mistrust connection and denial It explores this new wave of social media and technological connections however the film really highlights our generations lack of human interaction and need to live inside their social conscience unable to listen to their own

This is a film which simply shouldn t work but it does magnificently A story centred on a teenager who becomes the world s youngest billionaire a web site that reaches a million users in two years and a cast of real life characters with names like Zuckerberg and Winklevoss just shouldn t be possible A convoluted tale of raw conflict on the origins of a new type of web site should not lend itself to an expensive movie as opposed to a television documentary It succeeds because it is not about the technology but about creativity and conflict and about friendship and betrayal It succeeds because of a magical combination of accomplished direction scintillating dialogue and superb acting

The Social Network is a masterpiece of modern cinema that explores the origins of Facebook and the legal battle that followed its creation Directed by David Fincher and written by Aaron Sorkin the film boasts a star studded cast including Jesse Eisenberg Andrew Garfield and Justin Timberlake The film is a tour de force of storytelling weaving together multiple timelines and perspectives to create a gripping and immersive narrative Eisenberg gives a career defining performance as Mark Zuckerberg the brilliant and socially awkward Harvard student who becomes the founder of Facebook The film is both a character study of Zuckerberg and a commentary on the social and cultural impact of Facebook It explores themes of friendship betrayal power and the pursuit of success in the tech industry The dialogue is sharp witty and memorable capturing the cadence of real life conversations while adding a layer of drama and tension The supporting cast is equally impressive with Garfield shining as Zuckerberg s former best friend and business partner Eduardo Saverin and Timberlake stealing the show as the flamboyant and charismatic entrepreneur Sean Parker The cinematography is stylish and sleek capturing the energy and excitement of Silicon Valley and the fast paced world of tech startups The soundtrack composed by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross is haunting and atmospheric adding another layer of depth and emotion to the film Overall The Social Network is a triumph of modern cinema a gripping and thought provoking exploration of the rise of Facebook and its impact on society With its masterful storytelling powerful performances and stylish direction it is a must see film for anyone interested in the intersection of technology culture and business

The Social Network has a great story to tell about the rise of facebook and the journey Mark Zuckerberg made to get to where he is I was very disappointed to find out that it wasn t about this it was more about the dispute between Zuckerberg and his friend Eduardo Saverin The story the movie tells about the creation of facebook is to my dismay littered with fiction It felt like the director based the character of Zuckerberg not based on the original but on a slightly different version of Zuckerberg who is a insecure and asinine genius They portray his character this way by changing a few things about the real story of Zuckerberg In reality Mark Zuckerberg is none of these things and the portrayal of him in the movie is so far off from reality it hurts Aside from this flaw the movies main focus as far as plot is not the rise of facebook and the different challenges the team face but the relationship between Mark and Eduardo In fact the movie is almost entirely about their feud This makes sense seeing as how the movie is based off the book The Accidental Billionaires The Founding of Facebook A Tale of Sex Money Genius and Betrayal A book that tells the story of how facebook was created without any help from the creator of facebook himself Mark Zuckerberg Instead the author received a lot of help from the friend of Mark s who only funded the project Eduardo It s frustrating how to think that they would make a movie after such a crappy book but there really isn t much we can do about it now In conclusion I wish this movie had never been made 0 stars
